questions.text: Indications of Moskowitz repair include? (PGI TYPE)
True regarding fibroid in pregnancy? (PGI TYPE)

options.label: A
options.text: Carneous degeneration may occur in pregnancy

options.label: B
options.text: May not increase in size in pregnancy

options.label: C
options.text: 1% cases may undergo sarcomatous change due to pregnancy

options.label: D
options.text: Broad ligament fibroid are small and can lead to menstrual irregularity in non-pregnant females

options.label: E
options.text: Hydroureter is mostly caused by anterior wall intramural fibroid

questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Option A is correct. Carneous degeneration is a subtype of haemorrhagic infarction of leiomyomas that often occurs during pregnancy. On gross pathology, it is characterised by a red (haemorrhagic) appearance of the leiomyoma. Red degeneration primarily occurs secondary to venous thrombosis within the periphery of the tumour or rupture of intratumoral arteries Option B is correct. Majority of fibroids do not increase in size during pregnancy Option C is incorrect. Option D is incorrect. They are large and not associated with menstrual irregularities
  • • Option A is correct. Carneous degeneration is a subtype of haemorrhagic infarction of leiomyomas that often occurs during pregnancy. On gross pathology, it is characterised by a red (haemorrhagic) appearance of the leiomyoma. Red degeneration primarily occurs secondary to venous thrombosis within the periphery of the tumour or rupture of intratumoral arteries
  • • Option B is correct. Majority of fibroids do not increase in size during pregnancy
  • • Option C is incorrect.
  • • Option D is incorrect. They are large and not associated with menstrual irregularities
  • • Option E is incorrect.

questions.text: Clinical case of abnormal uterine bleeding comes. Management of endometrial hyperplasia without atypia shall include? (PGI TYPE)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Identify and manage risk factors like obesity Progestins are the first line therapy The LNG-IUS should be the first-line medical treatment because compared with oral progestogens it has a higher disease regression rate with a more favourable bleeding profile and it is associated with fewer adverse effects. Continuous progestogens should be used (medroxyprogesterone 10–20 mg/day or norethisterone 10–15 mg/day) for women who decline the LNG-IUS. Cyclical progestogens should not be used because they are less effective in inducing regression of endometrial hyperplasia without atypia compared with continuous oral progestogens orthe LNG-IUS Treatment with oral progestogens or the LNG-IUS should be for a minimum of 6 months in order to induce histological regression of endometrial hyperplasia without atypia. If adverse effects are tolerable and fertility is not desired, women should be encouraged to retain the LNG-IUS for up to 5 years as this reduces the risk ofrelapse, especially if it alleviates abnormal uterine bleeding symptoms.
  • • Identify and manage risk factors like obesity
  • • Progestins are the first line therapy The LNG-IUS should be the first-line medical treatment because compared with oral progestogens it has a higher disease regression rate with a more favourable bleeding profile and it is associated with fewer adverse effects. Continuous progestogens should be used (medroxyprogesterone 10–20 mg/day or norethisterone 10–15 mg/day) for women who decline the LNG-IUS. Cyclical progestogens should not be used because they are less effective in inducing regression of endometrial hyperplasia without atypia compared with continuous oral progestogens orthe LNG-IUS Treatment with oral progestogens or the LNG-IUS should be for a minimum of 6 months in order to induce histological regression of endometrial hyperplasia without atypia. If adverse effects are tolerable and fertility is not desired, women should be encouraged to retain the LNG-IUS for up to 5 years as this reduces the risk ofrelapse, especially if it alleviates abnormal uterine bleeding symptoms.
  • • The LNG-IUS should be the first-line medical treatment because compared with oral progestogens it has a higher disease regression rate with a more favourable bleeding profile and it is associated with fewer adverse effects. Continuous progestogens should be used (medroxyprogesterone 10–20 mg/day or norethisterone 10–15 mg/day) for women who decline the LNG-IUS. Cyclical progestogens should not be used because they are less effective in inducing regression of endometrial hyperplasia without atypia compared with continuous oral progestogens orthe LNG-IUS Treatment with oral progestogens or the LNG-IUS should be for a minimum of 6 months in order to induce histological regression of endometrial hyperplasia without atypia. If adverse effects are tolerable and fertility is not desired, women should be encouraged to retain the LNG-IUS for up to 5 years as this reduces the risk ofrelapse, especially if it alleviates abnormal uterine bleeding symptoms.
  • • The LNG-IUS should be the first-line medical treatment because compared with oral progestogens it has a higher disease regression rate with a more favourable bleeding profile and it is associated with fewer adverse effects.
  • • Continuous progestogens should be used (medroxyprogesterone 10–20 mg/day or norethisterone 10–15 mg/day) for women who decline the LNG-IUS.
  • • Cyclical progestogens should not be used because they are less effective in inducing regression of endometrial hyperplasia without atypia compared with continuous oral progestogens orthe LNG-IUS
  • • Treatment with oral progestogens or the LNG-IUS should be for a minimum of 6 months in order to induce histological regression of endometrial hyperplasia without atypia.
  • • If adverse effects are tolerable and fertility is not desired, women should be encouraged to retain the LNG-IUS for up to 5 years as this reduces the risk ofrelapse, especially if it alleviates abnormal uterine bleeding symptoms.
